steps.desc: This is the front of our origami paper, the body of our hen will end up being this colour.
This is the back of the origami paper, the hens head will be this colour.
Fold the paper in half so that you have a triangle.
Fold the top layer down a little from the top. The fold is about 1/5 of the height, but it doesn't have to be exact.
Flip the paper over to the other side and fold the top point down the same amount.
Fold the triangular flap up, leaving a small gap.
Fold the paper in half, from left to right.
Fold the right flap to the left, at an angle. This fold can be adjusted to give your chicken a different position.
Fold the flap back on the other side to match the previous fold.
Rotate the paper to this position.
Make a fold on the front layer of the right section. The fold starts from the top of the "beak" down to the corner of the "wing".
Flip the chicken over to the other side. Repeat the last step and also flatten the top part so it becomes a point.
You can now adjust the folds of the wings and body so that the origami hen can sit up.
Here is the final chicken.
This is the back of our origami paper, which is usually white.
This is the front of our origami paper, our crow will be this colour, start this side up.
We will start by making a square base. Fold the bottom right corner diagonally up to the top left corner. (skip to page 2, step 14 if you already know the square base)
Unfold the previous step.
Fold the bottom left corner diagonally up to the top right corner.
Unfold the previous step.
Flip the paper over to the other side.
Fold the right edge over to the left edge.
Unfold the previous step.
Fold the bottom edge up to the top edge.
Unfold the previous step.
Rotate the paper.
Collapse the top point down and the left and right points inwards.
Flatten the paper, this is the origami square base.
Fold the lower left and right edges to the middle.
Fold the top point down, along the top edges of the flaps you made in the previous step.
Unfold the previous step.
Lift up the flap from the bottom and bring it upwards.
Flatten the flap upwards, reversing the creases until you have a neat diamond shape.
Repeat step 15 onwards to the other side. We will start by making a square base. Fold the bottom right corner diagonally up to the top left corner.
Fold the bottom two points up about a third of the way up.
Focusing on the right side, fold the flap diagonally down to the right.
Open the flap and flatten it into a sideways kite shape as shown.
Fold the top of the flap down.
Repeat step 23 onwards on the left side.
Fold the front layer downwards.
Flip the model over to the other side, from left to right.
Fold the right section over to the left.
To shape the head, fold the top point diagonally over to the left.
Unfold the previous step and inside reverse fold the crease.
Your origami crow is complete!
Try perching the crow on the edge of the table.
1. This is the front of our origami paper, the dove will end up being this colour.
2. Make sure your paper is flipped to the back of the origami paper, sometimes white.
3. Fold the bottom point up to the top point and crease well.
4. Fold the right point over to the left point.
5. Unfold the previous step.
6. Fold the bottom left and right points diagonally up to the top point.
7. Fold the top point of both flaps down to the bottom point.
8. Unfold the previous step.
9. Fold the left and right points in to meet the central vertical line.
10. Unfold the previous step.
11. Unfold the right section.
12. Using the creases you just made, bring the right side in.
13. Fold the right section back up, squashing the folds underneath.
14. Repeat steps 11 to 13 on the left side.
15. Flip the paper over, from left to right.
16. Fold the left edge over to the right edge. Make sure the open ends are at the top.
17. Bring the top layer diagonally down to the left.
18. Flip the paper over to the other side, from left to right.
19. Bring the top layer diagonally down to the right.
20. Fold the flap diagonally over and down to the left as shown.
21. Bring the other flap down from behind to match.
22. Fold the top point diagonally over to the left, using the creases underneath as a guide.
23. Open the model up a bit and place it in this position.
24. Bring the two sides inwards so that you have this.
25. Flatten the model again and rotate it to this position.
26. Fold the bottom left flap diagonally up to the right as shown.
27. Flip the paper over and repeat the last step on the other flap.
28. Rotate the paper, you can now see it's a bird!
29. Inside reverse fold the head by pinching the top point and pulling it down.
30. Flatten the head.
31. The origami dove is completed.
32. You can position the wings further up to make it look like the dove is flying.
1. This is the front of our origami paper, most of the bird will end up being this colour.
2. This is the back of our paper, the bird's head area will be this colour.
3. Fold the left point over to the right point.
4. Unfold the previous step.
5. Fold the lower left and right diagonal edges to the middle.
6. Flip the paper over to the other side.
7. Fold the top point down.
8. Flip the paper back over to the other side.
9. Fold the top left and right points diagonally inwards.
10. Unfold the previous step.
11. Open out the right side, reverse folding the front crease.
12. Flatten the point down completely.
13. Repeat the same process on the left side.
14. Fold the two flaps as shown. They will become the bird's feet.
15. Fold the right side over to the left.
16. Rotate the model, you can now start to see a bird take shape.
17. Time to make the bird's head and beak. Fold the top point over into the desired head shape.
18. Unfold the last step and open out the top end.
19. Inside reverse fold the beak, you can alter this as desired.
20. For the tail, fold the tip up, aligning with the back edge.
21. Fold the tip back down, leaving a gap.
22. Unfold the previous 2 steps and open the bird up so you can see inside.
23. Next re-fold the pleat folds inside the bird.
24. Re-fold the bird back together. If your bird has trouble standing, adjust the tail of the bird by pulling and re-folding into place.
25. Your origami bird is complete!
This is the front of our origami paper, the turkey will end up being this colour.
This is the back of our origami paper, which won't be visible at the end.
Fold the paper in half, from right to left so that you have a triangle.
Unfold the previous step.
Fold the left and right points diagonally to the centre to make a Kite shape.
Fold the top point down over the top of the two front flaps.
Open the left and right flaps.
Re-fold the left and right flaps over the top of the top flap.
Flip the paper over to the other side.
Fold the top left and right points diagonally down, aligning with the central crease.
Unfold the previous step and flip the paper back over to the other side.
Open out the right side.
Flatten the right side down as shown.
Open and flatten the left side as shown.
Fold the flaps up as shown.
Leaving a gap, fold the flaps back the other way.
Fold the model in half.
Rotate to this position.
Fold the right point diagonally up as shown.
Fold the left point diagonally in as shown.
Unfold the previous two steps.
Open the model so that you can outside reverse fold the last two creases.
Flatten the model to this position as shown.
Create a head shape by folding the right point over.
Open the model out a bit and outside reverse fold the crease you just made.
The last step is to make an inside reverse fold at the end of the "beak".
You can now stand your turkey up.
1. This is the front of our origami paper, our swan will be mostly this colour.
2. Flip the paper over to the back, origami paper is usually white on this side.
3. Fold the right point over to the left point creating a central vertical crease.
4. Unfold the previous step.
5. Fold the lower left and right diagonal edges to align with the central vertical crease.
6. Flip the paper over to the other side.
7. Fold the left and right diagonal edges to the central vertical crease.
8. Fold the bottom point up to the top point.
9. Fold the top point down, creating the swan's head.
10. It's easier if you rotate the model.
11. Fold the top section in half and behind as shown.
12. Pull on the swan's head and refold the lower right creases once you have a position you like.
13. Pull up the swans head in the same was as the previous step.
14. The origami swan is complete!
1. This is the front of the paper, our origami flapping bird will end up being this color.
2. This is the back of the paper, usually white.
3. Fold the right edge of the paper over to the left edge.
4. Unfold the paper.
5. Fold the bottom edge up to the top edge.
6. Unfold the paper.
7. Flip the paper over to the other side.
8. Fold the bottom right corner diagonally up to the top left corner.
9. Unfold the previous step.
10. Fold the bottom left corner up to the top right corner.
11. Unfold the previous step.
12. Flip the paper over to the other side.
13. Bring the bottom left and top right corners forward and down, collapsing the top.
14. Rotate the paper so that the open end is at the bottom.
15. Fold the left and right lower diagonal edges inwards to align with central vertical crease.
16. Unfold the previous step.
17. Fold the top point down from the top points of the previous creases.
18. Unfold the previous step.
19. Pull up one layer from the bottom point and bring it upwards. You will need to reverse fold the creases.
20. Flatten out the paper to become a diamond shape.
21. Flip the paper over to the other side.
22. Repeat steps 18 to 20 on this side.
23. Fold the top pint down to the middle.
24. Flip one layer from the right over to the left.
25. Flip one layer from the back over to the right.
26. Fold both of the lower points up, these form the “wings” of the flapping bird.
27. Pull the top right inner point down to the right until it's almost level with the horizontal crease on the wings. This forms the tail.
28. Pull the inner left section down to the left until it's aligned as shown. This forms the neck.
29. Pull out the beak and crease it in your preferred position.
30. Curl the wings, curl them towards the bird's head a little.
31. Fold the wings down a little, then tug on the tail gently, outwards away from the head.
32. You may need to adjust the curl of the wings and the level of the wings in order for it to 'flap'. Hold onto the bird's lower neck whilst pulling the tail.
This is the front of our origami paper, this colour will be our fly's main colour.
This is the back of our origami paper.
Fold the bottom point up to the top point.
Fold the bottom right point diagonally up to the top point.
Fold the bottom left point diagonally up to the top point.
Fold the right flap down at a slight diagonal as shown.
Fold the left flap to match the other flap.
Fold one layer from the top down, it should reach the top of the creases you made in the previous step.
Fold the top flap down to meet the edge of the front flap.
Unfold the previous step.
Fold the top point down, aligning the crease on the top layer with the flap behind it. You can also just estimate these folds.
Flip the paper over to the other side.
Fold the left and right sides inwards as shown.
You can also fold the edges from this side as it's easier to see the best position for the flaps.
You can finally fold the top left and right corners over a little, to make the eyes of the fly.
This is the front of the origami paper, the cicada will have this as its main colour.
This is the back of the origami paper.
Fold the top point down to the bottom point.
Fold the top right point diagonally down to the bottom point.
Fold the top left point down to the bottom point.
Fold both flaps up to the top point. You can also angle these flaps outward a bit, this will make the wings further apart.
Fold one layer from the bottom up, leaving a small gap.
Fold the bottom point up, again leaving a gap.
Rotate the paper and flip it over to the other side.
Fold the left and right edges to meet in the middle. You can overlap them slightly so that you can slot one into the other.
Flip the paper over to the other side. You can now decorate your cicada if you wish!
This is the front of our origami paper, our fox will end up being this colour all over.
This is the back of our origami paper, which will not be seen.
Fold the bottom point up to the top point. Make this as neat as possible.
Fold the bottom right point up to the top point.
Fold the bottom left point up to the top point.
Flip the paper over from right to left.
Fold the right point over to the left point.
Rotate the paper a little counter-clockwise. The open points should be at the top.
Fold the left edge - all layers - on a slight diagonal to the right.
Let the flaps open back to the left. You can now see the shape of the fox.
Fold the fox's face down.
Pick up the model and play around with the front legs until the fox can stand on his own. Finally you can draw a face if you like!
This is the front of our origami paper, this red colour will be the only visible colour on our ladybug.
This is the back of our paper, which won't be visible.
Fold the paper diagonally in half by bringing the top point down to the bottom point.
Next fold the right point over to the left point.
Unfold the previous step. You now have a central vertical crease.
Fold the right point down from the top of the vertical crease, with the bottom point just sticking out to the right a little.
Fold the left point to match the opposite side.
Flip the paper over to the other side from left to right.
Fold the top point down a bit, almost to the same level as the left and right corners.
Fold the top flap back up, leaving a small section behind.
Flip the paper back over to the other side, you can see the shape is almost complete.
Fold the left and right points behind, making the ladybug a more rounded shape.
Finally, you can decorate your ladybug. We suggest some simple black pencil or pen, alternatively, you could cut out some circles and stick them on.
Start by making an origami whale. Click here for the tutorial.
Unfold the whale to this point.
Fold the inner left section over to the left, leaving a small gap.
Fold the whale back in half and then pull the narwhal's tusk into a good position.
This is what the inside looks like after re-positioning the narwhal's tusk.
The origami narwhal is done!
This is the front of the origami paper.
This is the back of origami paper, this color won't be seen, start this side up.
Starting with the paper rotated to a diamond, fold the right point over to the left point.
Unfold the previous step. You now have a central vertical crease.
Fold the lower left and right diagonal edges to the central vertical crease.
Flip the paper over to the other side and rotate it counter clockwise.
Fold the right point over to the left to meet the left point.
Flip the paper over to the other side.
Fold the top and bottom diagonal edges inwards to meet the horizontal middle.
Unfold the previous step.
Open the lower section as shown.
Pull the lower section fully over to the right, creating a new crease, and flatten it out.
Repeat the same process on the top section.
Unfold the back layer out to the right.
Fold the front flaps to the left.
Flip the paper over, from top to bottom.
Fold the left point to the central vertical crease.
Fold the bottom section up to the top, revealing the shape of the whale.
Fold both of the whale's flippers to the right at an angle.
To shape the tail, fold it up at an angle as shown.
Open the paper back up to this point.
Reverse inside fold the tail.
Fold the whale back up. The traditional origami whale is complete!
Optionally, you can also make a single cut with scissors where shown.
Fold the top tail point diagonally as shown.
Now finally fold the whale back in half, now the tail is more like a dolphin or fish tail.
With the split tail, you could also curl the points down, like some kinds of whales have.
This is the front of our origami paper, our origami turtle will end up this color.
This is the back of our paper, which if using origami paper, is often white. Start this side up.
Fold the paper diagonally in half so that you have a triangle shape.
Fold the bottom right point up to the top point.
Fold the bottom left point up to the top point.
Fold both points down to the bottom point.
Fold both bottom points diagonally outwards as shown.
Rotate the paper.
Using scissors, cut where indicated. Cut only the front-most layer of paper.
Fold the two flaps outward to match the ones at the top.
Fold the top point down.
Fold the top flap back upwards, leaving a small gap, this is a pleat fold.
Fold the left and right points to the middle.
Unfold the previous step and fold the left and right points again but this time leave a small gap.
Finally, push the left and right sides in again, this will give the turtle a more 3D look and allow the feet to rest underneath the turtle.
Flip the origami turtle over to the other side and adjust the legs however you like. You could draw a little face on the turtle as well.
This is the front of our origami paper, the origami mouse will be mostly this colour.
This is the back of our origami paper, which is often white. Start this side up.
Fold the top point down to the bottom point.
Unfold the previous step.
Fold the right point over to the left point.
Unfold the previous step.
Fold the lower left and right diagonal edges to the middle.
Unfold the previous step.
Fold the top left and right diagonal edges to the middle.
Re-fold the lower right diagonal crease and pinch the right point outward.
Flatten the point upwards.
Repeat the last 2 steps on the left side.
Rotate the paper so that the front flaps are pointing to the left.
Fold the 2 front flaps to the right.
Fold the 2 front flaps back to the left.
Fold the lower flap diagonally to the right aligning with the central vertical crease.
Fold the upper flap diagonally down in the same way.
Unfold the previous step and fold the lower flap to the right.
Fold the upper flap over to the right so that it rests on top.
Fold the right point over to where the left-most diagonal creases come together.
Unfold the previous step.
Flip the paper over to the other side, keeping the crease you just made on the right.
Refold the previous crease to the left.
Fold the top right and bottom right diagonal edges in aligning with the central crease.
Fold the top section down in half.
Flatten the paper, and rotate to this position.
Fold the left point over to the right, using the pre-existing crease line and the lower right point as a guide.
Fold the flap back over to the left, leaving a gap as shown.
Open the paper out to this position and reverse inside fold the last 2 creases.
Fold the paper back to this position.
Look under the mouse and fold the bottom of the tail underneath.
Fold the ears backwards a little.
Using a finger or pencil, open the ears so they look rounded.
The traditional origami mouse is complete.
You can fold the lower section under to give your origami mouse different poses.
1. This is the front of the paper, our origami butterfly will end up being this colour.
2. This is the back of the origami paper.
3. Fold the top left corner diagonally down to the bottom right corner.
4. Unfold the previous step.
5. Fold the top right corner diagonally down to the bottom left corner.
6. Unfold the previous step.
7. Flip the paper over to the other side.
8. Fold the bottom edge up to the top edge.
9. Unfold the previous step.
10. Flip the paper back over to the other side.
11. Push the left and right sides inwards, collapsing the top edge down to the bottom edge.
12. Flatten the paper to form a triangle. (This is a water bomb base)
13. Fold the bottom left and right points diagonally up to meet the top point.
14. Flip the model over to the other side.
15. Fold the bottom edge up, a little more than half way.
16. Flip the paper over to the other side.
17. Bring the two flaps down.
18. Flatten the two flaps down, squashing the left and right edges.
19. Flip the butterfly over to the other side.
20. Fold the top triangle down.
21. Fold the top triangular flap up, leaving a little gap.
22. Flip the butterfly back over to the other side.
23. Fold the left side over to the right, careful not to rip the little flaps in the middle. Take note of the white valley fold line (in white) for the next step.
24. Fold the top layer back diagonally to the left, along the imaginary line in the previous step. This doesn't have to be exact, folding at different angles will result in a different end result.
25. Repeat the last step on the other side.
26. You can bring the two inner edges together.
27. The butterfly is complete!
1. This is the front of the paper, our fox's mouth will be this colour.
2. This is the back of the paper, our fox's ears will be this colour.
3. Fold the right edge of the paper over to the left.
4. Unfold the paper.
5. Fold the top edge of the paper down to the bottom edge.
6. Fold the right edge to align with the central vertical crease that you created in the previous step.
7. Fold the left edge to meet the central crease.
8. Fold the top left point of the right section diagonally down to the right.
9. Unfold the previous step.
10. Open out the right section.
11. Flatten the right section, using the diagonal crease to create a house shape.
12. Repeat the same process on the left side.
13. Flip the paper over to the other side.
14. Fold the right edge to the middle.
15. Fold the left edge to the middle too.
16. Fold the top layer of the bottom right point diagonally up to the left.
17. Fold the top layer of the bottom section diagonally up, creating a crease that runs from the bottom left corner up to the top right corner of the lower section.
18. Fold the front layer up to the top. This has created an ear.
19. Flip the model over to the other side.
20. Repeat the same process on this side, but this time it's the left side.
21. Fold the bottom left point diagonal up.
22. Fold the bottom section up to create the other ear.
23. Rotate the model so that it's as shown.
24. Pull the model open from behind and squash the mouth inwards.
25. When you close the mouth completely, you will be able to straighten out the nose creases.
26. The origami fox puppet is complete.
27. Use your hand to open and close the foxes mouth just like a cloth or sock puppet.
1. This is the front of our origami paper, the frog will end up being this colour.
2. This is the back of the paper, this colour will not be visible on our final frog.
3. Fold the right edge over to the left edge.
4. Fold the top right corner diagonally down to align with the left edge.
5. Unfold the previous step.
6. Fold the top left corner diagonally down to align with the right edge.
7. Unfold the previous step.
8. Flip the paper over to the other side.
9. Fold the top edge down to meet the lower ends of the diagonal creases you just made.
10. Unfold the previous step.
11. Flip the paper back over to the other side.
12. Bring the top left and right edges forward and down, flattening the paper into a triangle shape.
13. Fold the bottom edge up to meet the bottom of the triangular top section.
14. Fold the right edge over to the middle, you can fold the right side of the top triangle over to the left if you need to.
15. Repeat on the left side.
16. Fold the bottom edge up to align with the bottom of the triangle.
17. Fold the top left and right corners of the lower flap diagonally inwards and down.
18. Unfold the last couple of steps.
19. Bring the inner corners of the lower section up and outwards to create a boat shaped flap.
20. Fold the right and left lower points downwards.
21. To make the frog's back legs, fold the points diagonally outwards.
22. Fold the left and right corners of the top triangular section diagonally up.
23. Fold the bottom of the frog up along the center.
14. Fold the edge back down, creating a pleat. This will be the frog's 'spring'.
25. The origami frog is complete, use your finger and hold the back edge down and the frog will spring up and away.
